choices.text: Superior turbinate
Middle turbinate
Inferior turbinate
Nasal septum

questions.text: During a diagnostic nasal endoscopy of a 35-year-old male presenting with nasal obstruction and sinus headaches, a structure is visualised projecting from the lateral nasal wall just inferior to the skull base and superior to the inferior turbinate. It is marked by a black arrow in the image provided. Identify this anatomical structure.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shown is an endoscopic view of the nasal cavity, and the part marked is the middle turbinate. It appears pinkish, smooth, and curved, which is the normal appearance.

Middle Turbinate:

  • The middle turbinate is a bony projection from the ethmoid bone, forming part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It plays an essential role in:
    • Dividing airflow
    • Protecting the osteomeatal complex (drainage area of frontal, anterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses)
    • Serving as a key landmark in nasal endoscopy and sinus surgery
  • Concha bullosa: A Pneumatized (air-filled) middle turbinate can cause nasal obstruction or sinusitis

Turbinate Anatomy:

Explanation of other options:

  • Nasal Septum (Option D) is the flat, vertical midline structure that divides the nasal cavities and lies medially to all the turbinates.

choices.text: The inspiratory and expiratory air currents pass through the middle part of the nasal cavity
Sinuses are mainly ventilated during the expiratory phase of respiration
Nasal cilia beat 10-20 times per second, and the mucociliary clearance time is 10-20 minutes
The rhythmic congestion and decongestion are seen in vasomotor rhinitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the physiology of the nose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The nasal cycle of rhythmic congestion and decongestion is seen in all normal individuals.The duration of this cycle varies every 2.5 to 4 hours.
  • This occurs because of the autonomic nerve supply of the nose.
  • Nasal mucosa has a rich blood supply. Sympathetic stimulation causes vasoconstriction and shrinkage of the mucosa, while parasympathetic stimulation causes vasodilation and engorgement.
  • The autonomic system is unstable in cases of vasomotor rhinitis. So the rhythmic congestion and decongestion are

Explanation of other options:

  • The inspiratory and expiratory air currents pass through the middle part of the nasal cavity(Option A):The middle part of the nasal cavity (particularly the middle meatus) plays a major role in directing both inspiratory and expiratory airflow.It is a key region for warming, humidifying, and filtering the air.
  • Sinuses are mainly ventilated during the expiratory phase of respiration(Option B):The paranasal sinuses are ventilated primarily during expiration.This phase creates a slight positive pressure that helps push air into the sinuses, aiding gas exchange and drainage.
  • Nasal cilia beat 10-20 times per second, and the mucociliary clearance time is 10-20 minutes(Option C):Nasal cilia beat at a frequency of 10-20 Hz (beats per second).The mucociliary clearance time (nasal transit time) is approximately 10-20 minutes, which is essential for clearing debris and pathogens.

choices.text: Middle part of the cavity in the middle meatus in a parabolic curve
Lower part of the cavity in the inferior meatus in a parabolic curve
Superior part of the cavity in the superior meatus
Through olfactory area

questions.text: During inspiration, the main current of airflow in a normal nasal cavity is through:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During inspiration, air current passes through the middle part of the nose between the turbinates and the nasal septum in a parabolic curve. Ensures efficient warming, humidification, filtration, and optimal exposure of inspired air to sinus and mucosal surfaces.
  • During expiration, friction offered at the limen nasi converts part of the air currents into eddies under the cover of inferior and middle turbinates, and this ventilates the sinuses through the ostia.

choices.text: Neurons of the olfactory epithelium
Olfactory tract
Amygdala
Olfactory bulbs

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a loss of smell following a road traffic accident. He also reports clear, watery nasal discharge that increases when he bends forward. CT scan reveals a fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The olfactory epithelium, located in the roof of the nasal cavity, contains olfactory receptor neurons, which are first-order sensory neurons responsible for detecting odorants.
  • These neurons send their axons through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone to synapse in the olfactory bulb.
  • A fracture of the cribriform plate can shear these delicate axons(not the cell bodies), leading to:
    • Loss of smell (anosmia)
    • CSF rhinorrhea (leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the nose), especially when bending forward.
  • Esthesioneuroblastoma(Olfactory Neuroblastoma) arises from the olfactory epithelium.

Explanation of other options:

  • Olfactory tract (Option B): The olfactory tract carries signals from the olfactory bulb to higher brain centers and is located posterior to the bulb, inside the cranial cavity, making it less directly affected by a cribriform plate fracture.
  • Amygdala (Option C): This is a limbic system structure involved in emotional responses to smell, but not involved in odour detection. It is located deep in the brain (medial temporal lobe), not near the cribriform plate.
  • Olfactory bulbs (Option D): These receive input from olfactory receptor neurons but are located superior to the cribriform plate, inside the cranial cavity.

choices.text: Upper 1/3rd bony and lower 2/3rd is cartilaginous
The Cartilaginous part is made of 3 paired and 1 unpaired cartilages
The Ethmoid bone does not contribute to the formation of the bony part
The Cottle test checks the patency of the nasal valve

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the external nose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ethmoid bone contributes to the formation of the bony part of the nose.

Bony and Cartilaginous Components of the External Nose:

  • 3 Major Components of the Nasal Septum:
    • Anteriorly: Septal quadrangular cartilage
    • Superiorly: Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
    • Posteriorly: Vomer
  • 4 Minor Contributing Bones:
    • Spine of the axilla
    • Spine of the frontal bone
    • Rostrum of the sphenoid
    • Crests of the palatine and maxillary bones

choices.text: Bleeding polypus of the septum is the most common benign tumour of the nasal cavity
Osteoma are the most common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses
The Frontal sinus is called the Antrum of Highmore
Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is more common in children.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the right statement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The maxillary sinus is called the Antrum of Highmore.

  • It is the largestof the paranasal sinuses and occupies the body of the
  • It is pyramidalwith the base towards the lateral wall of the noseand the apex directed laterally into the zygomatic process of the maxilla and sometimes into the zygomatic bone itself
  • Has a capacity of 15 mL in an adult. It is 33 mm high, 35 mm deep and 25 mm wide.

Explanation of other options:

  • Bleeding polypus of the septum is the most common benign tumour of the nasal cavity(Option A):Also known as a lobular capillary hemangioma, bleeding polypus of the septum is indeed one of the most common benign tumors of the nasal cavity, particularly the anterior septum.Presents with recurrent epistaxis (nosebleeds) and a reddish, vascular polypoidal mass.
  • Osteoma are the most common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses(Option B):Osteomas are slow-growing benign bony tumors.They are most commonly found in the frontal and ethmoid sinuses.Often asymptomatic but can cause obstruction or sinusitis if large.
  • Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is more common in children's (Option D):In children, maxillary osteomyelitis is more common due to Higher vascularity and porosity of the pediatric maxilla.More prone to infections, especially from dental or upper respiratory origins.In contrast, mandibular osteomyelitis is more common in adults due to poor vascular supply.

choices.text: Maxillary
Sphenoid
Frontal
Posterior ethmoid

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses is not visible on Water's View?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All sinuses can be seen in Water’s view except the Posterior ethmoid air cells.
  • Anterior ethmoid cells may be partially seen, but the view is not reliable for full assessment
  • The ethmoid sinus is seen in the Caldwell view.

Waters' View (occipitomental view or nose-chin position):

  • Structures seen are:
    • Maxillary sinuses (seen best). (Option A)
    • Frontal sinuses. (Option C)
    • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with the mouth open). (Option B)
    • Zygoma
    • Zygomatic arch.
    • Nasal bone.
    • Frontal process of the
    • Superior orbital fissure.
    • Intratemporal fossa

choices.text: Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1 to 8.
Anterior and posterior ethmoid air cells are separated by the basal lamella
Bulla ethmoidalis is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell
Anterior ethmoid air cells are 2 to 8

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ethmoid air cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The agger nasi cell, lying just anterior to the uncinate process at the frontal recess, is the most anterior ethmoid air cell.
  • The ethmoid bulla is instead the largest and most constant anterior ethmoid cell, but it is located posterior to the uncinate process, not the most anterior.
  • The two named constant cells of the anterior ethmoid group include:
    • Agger nasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell. It is also called the fourth turbinate.
    • Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest and most consistent anterior ethmoid air cell.
  • Anterior and posterior ethmoid air cells are separated by the basal lamella or ground lamella.(Option A ruled out)

choices.text: Bulla Ethmoidalis
Haller cell
Concha Bullosa
Onodi cell

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the NCCT of the nose and paranasal sinuses (marked with an arrow).
questions.solution:
The image with the arrow points to a cell inferior to the orbit, characteristic of a Haller cell.

  • Haller's cell is an anatomical variant of the anterior ethmoid air cells that extends into the orbital floor region, just below the orbit.
  • It can narrow the infundibulum and contribute to sinus drainage issues.

Variations of Ethmoid air cells are:

  • The onodi cell is a variation of the posterior ethmoid air cells and lies in close relation to the optic nerve. (Option D ruled out)
  • Haller's cell is a variation of the anterior ethmoid air cells and lies with the orbital floor. (Option B ruled out)
  • Concha bullosa is a variation of the anterior ethmoid air cells. It is the pneumatization of the middle turbinate. (Option C ruled out)

Reference:

  1. Scott-Brown's Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page Number: 973
  2. Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number: 159, 219.
